PRE-WAR -DISTRIBUTION OF THE TRADE AND SHIPPING OF THEBRITISH EMPIRE.prefatory note.The detailed tables attached were originally, prepared in the .Board of Trade "in April-May 1916, for the purpose of Showing for'aVepresentativ6 year, 1913, the value,-of the trade within the British Empire, and of the trade of the United Kingdom, India, and the Self-Governing Dominions, both severally and collectively,-with-Allied, Enemyfand Neutral Countries respectively;iand the: extent to which British; AlEedj-ifiiemy)and Neutral!-Tonnage participated in that year iu: the -carrying, trade between t,he United; Kingdom and the other parts of the British Empire, and in' the carrying trade of the British Empire generally. jFor the purposes of the present Return the term "Allies "has been applied to all' the countries actually at War with one or more of the Central Powers, or which have broken off diplomatic relations with one or more of those Powers. ,Since May 1916 the list of such countries has been considerably extended, and now includes 26 Foreign Countries. In four cases separate details require to be dealt with in respect of Overseas Possessions.As a result, very-considerable revision -as between Allies and Neutrals was necessary, and the opportunity has been taken to give separate figures for one or two important Neutral Countries formerly included under the general heading of South America. 'Egypt has, for the purposes of the Return, been treated as part of the British Empire.summary of results.1 - (a) Total Trade of the Empire.In 1913 the: value of the whole trade of the Empire reached the following amounts : - . .-. ... , . ,-. , , .. , -- - - Million fs.,Aggregate Imports '- ' A - '- - ' - '-'''-- '- - - - : - 1,444 -Aggregate Exports - -, - . . - - * - ... 1,295These totals include goods imported for' the purpose of being re-exported without undergoing any preliminary process of manufacture or adaptation.
